Since I love chatting about books, I‚Äôve been trying to share our family‚Äôs current reads on a regular basis here on the blog. And some fabulous new books have come out lately (including a few that I‚Äôm giving away to a lucky reader!) so I wanted to share the love!

Lately I Finished‚Ä¶:

Kristin Lavransdatter by Sigrid Undset

This is a re-read for me (4th re-read?) and it was even better than I remembered. I could write my own book about how much I love this book and why (in fact, I just wrote a long article about Kristin and Julia from Brideshead Revisited, my other fave) but here‚Äôs the short version: KL is a 20th century novel set in 14th century Norway inspired by Scandinavian sagas. Kristin is the most complex and well-crafted female protagonist I‚Äôve ever encountered. The characters are truly incredible and it‚Äôs about sin and grace which are probably the only things worth writing about anyway. Someday I‚Äôll write about how unlike any of L.M. Montgomery or Austen‚Äôs female characters, Kristin continues to be a REAL character after motherhood and not merely a background character. Very few (perhaps one or two) stories have stuck with me the way KL has. I beg you to read it, but I warn you, it‚Äôs LONG, a three-part story of over 1,100 pages. It definitely counts for my ‚ÄúLong Catholic Book‚Äù category of #cathLIT2019! And make sure you read the new Tiina Nunnally translation (I like reading it as three volumes instead of the giant one volume!)

Just Mercy by Bryan Stevenson

I borrowed this one from the library after it was recommended by my dad. It really is a must-read. I knew our justice system was horrifying but this book laid it all out in a way that deeply impacted me. Stevenson is a brilliant storyteller and manages to use powerful narrative to shed light on the institutional racism and discrimination against the poor in this country. Christy tells me I‚Äôm the last person in the universe to read it (I don‚Äôt read that many recently released books, I like old books), but if you haven‚Äôt read it yet, please do.

Current Reads:

The Secret History by Donna Tartt

I‚Äôm about 160 pages into this mystery that my dear friend Boze gave me for Christmas. It is a treat. Lots of the Oxford years from Brideshead vibes. Tartt is Catholic so this is going to be my ‚ÄúBook by a Catholic Novelist‚Äù category pick, but I guess it could also work for ‚ÄúBook by a Catholic Woman‚Äù!

The Voyage of the Dawn Treader by C.S. Lewis

We‚Äôre about to wrap up the 3rd book in the Chronicles of Narnia as our bedtime read!

The Giver by Lois Lowry

After the girls fall asleep, Benjamin and I usually spend a little extra time reading together and we just started this classic!
